utterances: And I'm Neal Conan here in Washington.
And with me in the studio are Mara Liasson, NPR national political correspondent, and John Ydstie, NPR economics correspondent.
And, Mara Liasson, let's go first to the politics and the president putting himself, it seems to me, squarely in the center.
A competitor, uh-oh.
Squarely in the center.
The White House strategy all along was to wait for Paul Ryan, the House Budget Committee chair, Republican, to go first, to lay out his vision.
They took a lot of hits.
The president took a lot of hits on leadership.
Why wasn't he stepping forward to solve these problems?
He was basically playing rope-a-dope, but this was their strategy, and you can see it working.
He was able to eviscerate Ryan, in his view, of Ryan's plan and vision, and explained why it was bad.
And then, he laid out his plan and why it's better.

He said that he can accomplish the same goals as Paul Ryan without hurting Medicare, without giving huge tax cuts to millionaires and billionaires, and also while retaining enough money to invest in things like education and research and development.
He did lay out his vision of progressive government, something the White House was telling us that he wouldn't do.
He wouldn't give a Brookings Institution-type speech is what I was told, but I actually think this was a Brookings Institution-type speech.

He said this is my vision for America, a vision where we live within our means while still investing in our future - where everyone makes sacrifices but no one bears all the burden - where we provide a basic measure of security for our citizens and rising opportunity for our children.
The White House believes the Ryan budget is imbalanced because it cuts too much out of programs for the poor and middle class without asking the rich or the defense - the Pentagon to share.
Well, one of the hits he was taking, John Ydstie, was that the president was ignoring his own commission, the so-called Simpson-Bowles commission.
And how much does this accord with their proposals which, well, we're calling - it was a bipartisan commission that called for deep cuts?
Well, he does, I think, in terms of non-security spending follow what the commission suggested, not as much in defense spending.

He does not cut as much from defense spending as they do, but he does call for $2 in cuts for every $1 in tax increases to try to close the deficit and another dollar in interest savings would come to get this $4 trillion in deficit reduction that he's saying he's got, or is his goal, over the next 12 years.
And I know that you've just had a few minutes to look at it, but broadly, do the numbers seem to add up?

You know, it is hard because it's not clear exactly what baseline they're operating from, but one question I have is the president in his original budget had one trillion dollars in deficit reduction.
He's now claiming another four trillion, and he says that's on top of the previous budget.
So I think we need to look more closely to see whether that's the case.
Of course, you know, there is not a detailed map for cutting here.
We don't know what kind of monies are going to come out (unintelligible) programs.
The devil in the details.

And this is a framework that he's laid out today, but a framework, I think, that he is happy to compare alongside chairman Paul Ryan's budget, the Republican proposal from the House of Representatives.
The president saying all along he welcomed this debate...
Yes.
...and now he's entered it, Mara.
Now, he's entered it, and also, he does really embrace the Bowles-Simpson vision.
He also gave a nod to the group of Republicans and Democrats in the Senate, the Gang of Six, who were trying to figure out a process to legislate the deficit commission's proposals into law.
I think the most important thing is not so much whether his numbers add up, but the fact that they have proposed this failsafe deficit trigger.

In other words, he says by 2014, if the debt is not projected to fall as a share of the economy or Congress has failed to act, there will be automatic spending cuts and spending reductions in the tax code...
Right.
...and that he says should be an incentive for us to act boldly now, instead of kicking our problems further down the road.
And, Mara...
Congress has done this before with pay-as-you-go legislation, Gramm-Rudman.
It has worked.
As we mentioned, in his view, eviscerated Paul Ryan's proposal.
He also addressed his critics in his own party.
Yes.
He certainly did.
He said to those of us who truly believe in my own party in a progressive vision of our society, we have the obligation to prove that we can afford our commitments.
If we believe the government can make a difference in people's lives, we have the obligation to prove that it works by making government smarter, leaner and more effective.
I think he did said a lot in here for Democrats.
He's not going to let Medicare be a voucher program.
He said as long as I'm president, tax cuts for the wealthy are going to expire.
I thought it was a rousing progressive speech, also balanced, stepped up to the plate on this, and, of course, the biggest difference is going to be on taxes.
That's where the Republicans have drawn their red line.
They don't want those tax cuts for the rich to expire at the end of 2012.
He knows that's going to be a big battle, but now, the battle is joined.
And it's very interesting.
Today, in a prebuttal, the speaker of the House said he'd just come back from the White House.
The president, obviously, is asking each leader to give four members for these negotiations that are going to start in May, but he says - I think the president is pretty serious about this as well.
That's John Boehner.
(Soundbite of music)
NPR's Mara Liasson.
Also with us, John Ydstie, NPR's economics correspondent.
Stay with us.
We're going to get more analysis from Maya MacGuineas, president of the Committee for a Responsible Budget.
We'll also be getting some political reaction from the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus and from Representative Jason Chaffetz of Utah, representing the 3rd District there.
Stay with us.
This is NPR News.
This is an NPR News special.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
About 10 minutes ago, President Obama wrapped up his proposals to bring down the federal deficit over the course of the next 12 years, four trillion dollars worth, he said.
And he said it was going to be a balanced approach.
Obey your thirst is right.
Happen to know the advertiser of the product?
Yes, there would be cuts, including cuts to entitlement programs like Medicaid and Medicare, but also, there were going to be tax increases.

We're going to be talking in just a moment to Maya MacGuineas of the Committee for a Responsible Budget, but with us on the phone right now is Congressman Jason Chaffetz, a Republican from Utah who represents the 3rd District.
Very good of you to be with us today.
Oh, well, thanks for having me on.
I hate this.
I don't want to bump Maya.
She's one of the smartest minds in the country.
So you better get to her.
We will, but we understand you have only a limited time so I wanted to get your reaction to the president's proposals.
Well, I thought it was high on political rhetoric.
It kind of centered - it sounded more like, again, a leadership speech that, see, I'm going to lead up by appointing Joe Biden to do the work.
It didn't have the substance that Paul Ryan's proposal has.
I think that's why - from my personal perspective, I think the president was panicking a little bit.
I think his budget proposal did not go off well.

There's a huge contrast and gulf with what the House Republicans had introduced, and consequently, he needed to get out there and try to scramble and say, hey, no, we are going to lead out on this stuff.
So it just lacks definition.
Yet, are we - do we have a debate now?
Do we have a clear set of proposals on one side and a clear set of proposals on another?
Well, you know, we looked back at the president's proposal and looked to what Paul Ryan proposed.
The president's budget doubles and then triples the debt.
Paul Ryan's proposal not only balances the budget but does end up paying off the debt.
So, yes, there's a huge contrast.
And just - when the vote comes, I believe, in the House of Representatives tomorrow on the continuing resolution, are you going to be in favor of that?

On the continuing resolution, I would probably vote no. I voted no on the other one, and I will vote no on this one because I don't think it's making as many cuts to our spending as I'd like to see it done.
I signed on to the Pledge for America and, you know, said that we are going to try to achieve a hundred billion dollars in cuts.
This falls short of that.
Well, Congressman, we know you're in a rush, and we appreciate your time to talk to us by cell phone.
Oh, thank you.
Congressman Jason Chaffetz, a representative from Utah.
He represents the 3rd District there, a Republican.
